user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    /*
     * In theory, this should wipe any existing files in the ramdisk,
     * but since ramdisks here are implemented using a directory within a tmpfs,
     * removal of such files could be risky if something goes wrong,
     * because it might remove files that were important.
     *
     * So the safest option is just a no-op.
     * (this is also backward compatible since POSIX mkfs was always a no-op)
     */
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl:
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function OS_FileSysFormatVolume_Impl contains no calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (no memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). It is a simple no-op that immediately returns OS_SUCCESS and does not reference or manipulate any buffers or pointer parameters (the token parameter is unused). The provided related definitions (OS_SUCCESS macro and the typedef for OS_object_token_t) do not introduce any string handling or buffer accesses. Therefore there are no code fragments in this submission that could cause accesses beyond object bounds via the <string.h> functions and nothing to investigate for Rule 21.17.
